bestBHT.bht: Filled with confusion and frustration, the disciples approached Jesus privately to understand their failure. They asked, Why could not we cast him out? Mark's usage of the interrogative particle οτ directly suggests their genuine inquiry into the reason behind their inability. They sought clarification from Jesus, fearing they had lost the power of driving out demons, as they had done before. In this moment of doubt, they sought answers and guidance from the Lord himself.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 28. Why could not we cast him out?
Philip Schaff: The question may mean: ‘We could not,’ etc., since the word with which it begins is often a mere mark of quotation." (Mark 9:28)
But it sometimes means 'why.' In that case the E.V. is correct." (Mark 9:28)
Others paraphrase: ‘How is it that we,’ etc." (Mark 9:28)
Archibald T. Robertson: The Revisers are here puzzled over Mark's use of οτ as an interrogative particle meaning why where Matthew 17:19 has δια τ.
It is probable that in these examples οτ really means why.
The use of ος as interrogative 'is by no means rare in the late Greek'.
John Gill: And when he was come into the house,.... Perhaps into the man's house whose child he had healed, or into some other in these parts, for the sake both of retirement and refreshment."
His disciples asked him privately, why could not we cast him out?"

The nine disciples, who were particularly concerned in this matter, fearing they had lost the power of casting out devils, conferred upon them, inquired of Jesus, when he was alone, why they could not cast the demon out of the child, when they had ejected unclean spirits out of many others.

bhtAttempts.bht: The disciples, filled with confusion and frustration, approached Jesus privately and asked, Why could not we cast him out? The use of the interrogative particle οτ in Mark's account poses a question of why rather than how. This indicates that the disciples were genuinely seeking an explanation for their inability to drive out the demon. In their private conversation with Jesus, they expressed their fear of losing the power they had previously displayed. It was in this moment of doubt that they turned to the Lord for answers and guidance.

Mark's usage of the interrogative particle οτ directly suggests their genuine inquiry into the reason behind their inability. They sought clarification from Jesus, fearing they had lost the power of driving out demons, as they had done before. In this moment of doubt, they sought answers and guidance from the Lord himself.

The disciples, filled with confusion and frustration, approached Jesus privately and asked, Why could not we cast him out? The disciples, fearing they had lost the power of casting out demons, sought an explanation for their inability to drive out the demon. They turned to Jesus in their moment of doubt, seeking answers and guidance from him. Mark's use of the interrogative particle οτ indicates that they genuinely desired to understand why they had failed.

The disciples, confused and perplexed, privately approached Jesus and asked, Why could not we cast him out? The disciples sought an explanation for their inability to drive out the demon, deeply concerned that they had lost their power. Mark's usage of the interrogative particle οτ suggests their genuine inquiry into the reason for their failure. In this moment of doubt and fear, they turned to Jesus, seeking clarity and guidance.

Filled with confusion and frustration, the disciples privately approached Jesus, wondering, Why could not we cast him out? Mark's use of the interrogative particle οτ indicates their genuine inquiry into the reason behind their inability to drive out the demon. Fearful that they had lost their power, the disciples sought an explanation from Jesus. In this moment of doubt, they turned to their teacher, seeking clarity and guidance on their faltering authority over unclean spirits.
